hobby.message: Analog photography still treating you right?
You still hunting political literature no one’s supposed to find?
Urban exploration or just drinking underground?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Depends who you ask. City’s glitching worse than usual lately.
Been out shooting film—analog, old hobby.
Harder now with all the score swings.
Sometimes I just leave it in the bag.
Rough week. BCI jumps making things interesting.
Still keep at my photography—only film, none of that digital trace.
Last time out, patrols were extra nosy about cameras.
Had to pack up sooner than I wanted.
Almost not worth the risk lately.
City’s mood’s as jittery as my hands loading film these days.
Analog photography—real film, real results. One of the few honest things left.
Those BCI blackouts nearly cost me a whole roll last night.
Was shooting around Oktyabr Square. Patrols everywhere, everyone on edge.
Even the light isn’t where it used to be.
Still, I can’t not try to capture it.
Honestly? It’s wearing thin. My camera’s seen better days—and so have I.
I only work in film, smuggled in. Never digital—feels like cheating anyway.
Last shoot, score spikes hit mid-frame. Streetlights blinked out, patrols everywhere, neighbors hiding.
Caught a raw shot of a woman’s BCI band glowing red—before she ducked the lens.
Patrols questioned me, barely let me off. That adrenaline lives in the negatives.
Developed everything in the basement. Every image feels heavier now.
It’s the only truth I trust anymore.
Bar’s the safest gallery left, Alex. You’re not likely to rat me out, but still.
I’m Rada—analog street photographer, since before the BCI even ran. Grew up with officers around, learned what not to show.
Now I smuggle film, shoot city shadows. Last week, Oktyabr Square: drones overhead, faces shutting down as scores dived.
I caught the panic. Sometimes, people notice and flinch. Sometimes, they want you to see.
Patrol stopped me. My pass is flagged from, well, ‘editorial disagreements.’ Barely got clear that evening.
Can’t process film at home anymore—locks glitch, always neighbors losing access.
But those photos? They’re real. Can’t fake what film sees. Not like the system edits on broadcast.
Bet my BCI’s tanked by now. Doesn’t matter. The city needs someone to remember what’s real.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still at it. Analog's all I've got left.
Film's hard to find these days, especially with checkpoints up.
Streets aren't safe for shooting. Not after the riots.
Sometimes I just hold the camera, no shots.
People are watching. Can't risk much.
Still chasing them, when I can get film past the patrols.
Snapped a couple during the blackout near Oktyabr Square.
Had to hide my camera more than usual lately.
Drones make steady shots tricky. Crowds on edge.
Hobby's not much of an escape now. Feels like surveillance runs both ways.
You never know who's scoring you out there.
Yeah, analog's the only way to see what's really happening.
Caught some real tension last week during those wild BCI swings.
Lighting's unpredictable—one minute bright, next total blackout.
Had security shake me down mid-roll. Claimed I was inciting unrest.
Negatives survived. People’s faces tell you the true story.
Nobody trusts broadcasts now. Photos feel like proof.
Film's hard to get, but worth every shot.
Of course. Analog’s the last honest witness I trust.
Took photos during the travel ban chaos in my old block.
Had to dodge extra patrols—the Directorate's everywhere now.
Developed film in a neighbor’s basement after my door got locked out.
Funny how BCI fluctuations show up on people's faces before the system even flags them.
Hobby’s riskier, but that’s how you find the humanity they want covered.
Blackouts make for haunting shadows in every frame.
Wish I could share them outside these walls.
Always. Chasing ghosts with analog is about the only real thing left.
Started back in my teens, before BCI ran everything.
Lately, every roll’s a gamble—lost a couple to sudden building sweeps.
Got stuck outside my apartment during a score crash. Lens on me, not through it.
Bar 101’s been my last darkroom. Alex, you know the routine.
Those wild swings—faces desperate, hopeful, all at once. No algorithm sees that.
Every patrol’s a reminder: this city edits its own truth.
Still hiding negatives. If they ever get out... well, it’s history in silver grains.
For me, the risk is proof the city’s still alive.
